para.paratext: Since the parol evidence rule protects only “valid” written instruments, parol evidence is admissible to show the invalidity of a writing for any proper reason,[1] such as the writing was a sham.[2]

Parol evidence may show a condition precedent that prevented a writing from becoming effective, but not a condition subsequent,[3] no delivery where delivery is essential to the validity of the writing,[4] consideration,[5] or the invalidity of a writing for fraud, mistake, duress, or illegality.[6]

Georgia courts do not allow parol evidence to show that delivery of a deed to the grantee was conditional, but do allow it to show no delivery at all.[7] Courts also disallow the use of the parol evidence rule to bar testimony in criminal trials.[8]

Georgia is especially strict where a party seeks to invalidate a contract on the basis of fraud when the party did not read the contract.[9] In Walker v. B. E. Robuck, Inc.,[10] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the defendant's allegation of fraud was good against demurrer and left the factual determination of whether the defendant was reasonably prevented from reading the contract by alleged artifice, trick, or device to the jury. In that case, the defendant alleged that she was about to read the contract when one of the plaintiff's agents took it from her and purported to read and explain it to her, including a contingency clause which was not, in fact, in the contract. Moreover, parol evidence is also not admissible to supply missing terms to a contract required to be in writing by the statute of frauds.[11] Also, parol evidence cannot be considered to alter the terms of a promissory note.[12]

In B. E. Robuck, Inc. v. Walker,[13] the Georgia Supreme Court reversed and held that the allegations were not sufficient against demurrer to show enough fraud to excuse the defendant from reading the contract. No confidential or fiduciary relationship existed between the parties in this case, which would have made parol evidence more readily admissible.[14]
O.C.G.A. §§ 24-3-1, 24-3-8; McCormick on Evidence § 221 (6th ed.).
However, Georgia follows a strict rule and such a condition can not be shown where it is contrary to the terms of the writing. Lyon v. Patterson, 138 Ga. App. 816, 227 S.E.2d 423 (1976).

O.C.G.A. § 24-6-8 [§ 24-3-8 eff. Jan. 1, 2013], which allows parol evidence to show that a writing is void, does not apply only where the plaintiff avers fraud with particularity in her complaint. If a party does not seek to contradict or vary the terms of a valid written instrument, but, rather, to show that a written instrument was void, a trial court errs when it excludes all parol evidence from consideration in ruling on a motion for summary judgment. Weatherly v. Weatherly, 292 Ga. App. 879, 665 S.E.2d 922 (2008).

Moreno v. Smith, 299 Ga. 443, 788 S.E.2d 349 (2016) (party may use parol evidence to show that no valid agreement ever went into existence; mother and daughter entered into an agreement to purchase real estate; daughter introduced parol evidence that the only reason they had signed the contract was so the mother could show that she had an interest in the real estate and was receiving rental income from it).
Heitman v. Commercial Bank of Savannah, 6 Ga. App. 584, 65 S.E. 590 (1909).
As to conditions precedent, see Citizens & Southern Nat. Bank v. Williams, 147 Ga. App. 205, 249 S.E.2d 289 (1978); Haraka v. Datry, 148 Ga. App. 642, 252 S.E.2d 71 (1979).
Crawford v. Foster, 6 Ga. 202, 1849 WL 1562 (1849).

If a contract is made under seal and recites nominal consideration, Georgia law conclusively presumes sufficient consideration, such that parol evidence may not be admissible. See, e.g., Jolles v. Wittenberg, 148 Ga. App. 805, 807, 253 S.E.2d 203 (1979) (conclusive presumption); Smith v. First Nat. Bank of Atlanta, 199 Ga. App. 858, 406 S.E.2d 519 (1991) (presumption of consideration with respect to guaranty executed under seal was conclusive, and fact that guarantor did not receive $5 recited was immaterial). Parol evidence is not permitted to show additional consideration where the note specifies monetary or valuable consideration. Lewis v. Ikner, 349 Ga. App. 21, 825 S.E.2d 443 (2019).

O.C.G.A. § 24-3-7; Beasley v. Huyett & Smith Mfg. Co., 92 Ga. 273, 18 S.E. 420 (1893); Superior Pine Products Co. v. Williams, 214 Ga. 485, 106 S.E.2d 6 (1958); Jackson v. Commercial Credit Corp., 90 Ga. App. 352, 83 S.E.2d 76 (1954); Friendly Finance Co. v. Stover, 109 Ga. App. 21, 134 S.E.2d 837 (1964).

Parol evidence is admissible to show that a contract was fraudulently induced and that a constructive trust on the disputed property should be imposed. Perry v. Perry, 285 Ga. App. 892, 648 S.E.2d 193 (2007); Jenkins v. Jenkins, 281 Ga. App. 756, 637 S.E.2d 56 (2006).
Some other jurisdictions are not as strict where the party did not have his glasses, compare Federal Land Bank of Omaha v. Houck, 68 S.D. 449, 4 N.W.2d 213 (1942).

The usual rule was applied in Simmons v. Wooten, 241 Ga. 518, 246 S.E.2d 639 (1978); Riker v. McKneely, 153 Ga. App. 773, 266 S.E.2d 553 (1980); Citizens Bank, Vienna v. Bowen, 169 Ga. App. 896, 315 S.E.2d 437 (1984); Malin v. Servisco, Inc., 172 Ga. App. 418, 323 S.E.2d 278 (1984).
Walker v. B. E. Robuck, Inc., 93 Ga. App. 820, 93 S.E.2d 178 (1956).
Lynchar, Inc. v. Colonial Oil Industries, Inc., 341 Ga. App. 489, 801 S.E.2d 576 (2017), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 303 Ga. 839, 815 S.E.2d 917 (2018).
Mashburn Construction, L.P. v. CharterBank, 340 Ga. App. 580, 798 S.E.2d 251 (2017).
B. E. Robuck, Inc. v. Walker, 212 Ga. 621, 94 S.E.2d 696 (1956).
Sutton v. McMillan, 213 Ga. 90, 97 S.E.2d 139 (1957).
In McWhorter, Ltd. v. Irvin, 154 Ga. App. 89, 267 S.E.2d 630 (1980), the confidential relationship of attorney and client was involved, so the “read-or-perish” rule did not apply.
